paragraphs.text: Chances of a TV election debate? Choose between zilch and nada.
paragraphs.label: title

paragraphs.text: At the time of the last election, David Cameron pronounced that TV debates were "here to stay"
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: It was his confident declaration that:"We will have them in every election in the future and that is a really good thing for democracy."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: Many others thought so too
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: More than 20 million people watched some or all of them
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: They engaged voters in ways that we hadn't seen before in Britain
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: To many, it was unthinkable that they wouldn't become a permanent feature of the fabric of our elections
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: It gives me no pleasure to say that I have always had great doubts that this was really the case
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: For it to be true, you had to trust the Tory leader not to change his mind
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: TV debates happened in 2010 only because of an unusual set of circumstances
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Mr Cameron had demanded them because that is what opposition leaders nearly always do
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Nick Clegg wanted to gain exposure that no previous third party leader had enjoyed
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: In the wake of the expenses scandal, all the parties were anxious to be seen trying to connect with alienated voters
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The key was Gordon Brown
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Unusually for a prime minister, he agreed to debates
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: His people thought he had little to lose and, in a typically Gordon Brownish way, he reckoned he would come over as the man of substance while his Tory and Lib Dem rivals would be exposed as lightweights
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: It didn't work out as Mr Brown expected
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: But
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: what is most relevant to what is happening now is that it didn't work out as Mr Cameron anticipated either
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The Lib Dem leader, an unknown to many voters before the debates, shone in the first one
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: presenting himself as the true candidate of change to the disadvantage of David Cameron and unleashing the "Cleggmania" that now seems so long ago
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: On election night, I was aboard the boat in the Thames hired by the BBC
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Among those also present to comment on the results was Michael Ashcroft, the Tory donor and pollster
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: As
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: it became clear that his party had failed to secure a majority
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: he placed the blame on the TV debates
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: That view has since become orthodoxy in the Conservative party
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Whether it is entirely true or not, it has been engraved into the Tory soul
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Two people were very badly burnt: Mr Cameron himself and George Osborne
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: who ran the last Tory election campaign and was widely castigated by his colleagues for agreeing to the debates
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The chancellor long ago told friends that he is not going to make the same mistake twice
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Lynton Crosby, the prime minister's Australian strategist, is also dead-set against TV debates
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Craig Oliver, the Number 10 communications chief who has been leading the Tory side in the debate negotiations, is another key figure who believes it is all downside for them
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The first reason that David Cameron and his advisers are against debates is the traditional one
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: He doesn't want to concede equality of status to his opponents
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The experience of the Clegg-Farage debates during the Euro elections hardened the belief in Number 10 that debates are bad for incumbents and a gift to challengers
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The view around Mr Cameron is expressed by one close ally:"If you are the incumbent, debates are heavily weighted in favour of the insurgents. It is a rigged game."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: It is not, as is often assumed, fear of Nigel Farage coming at him from the right that most worries the prime minister
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: His biggest concern is giving a boost to Ed Miliband
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: TV debates are the Labour leader's best remaining opportunity to secure mass exposure to voters sceptical that he is up to being prime minister and get them to reconsider their view
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: So poor are his personal ratings, Mr Miliband might only have to turn up and string together a few half-decent sentences and more people would think better of him
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The hope that their man could benefit by exceeding low expectations is why Labour is desperate for debates to happen
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Which makes the Tories equally desperate for them not to happen
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The Conservatives, as we saw last week with their "dodgy dossier" about Labour's spending plans, want to revert to an old-fashioned model of election in which the campaign is dominated by staged leaders' tours in which the prime minister wafts around the country looking presidential and morning news conferences designed, with a bit of help from their friends in the press, to shape the campaign to a Tory agenda
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: So, from the off, the Conservatives have done everything in their power to prevent TV debates from happening at this election
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The broadcasters and the other parties wanted to begin negotiations about the format last spring
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The Tories stalled
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: saying they wouldn't start talking until October
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: When the negotiations finally got under way, I am told, and by a variety of different sources, that the Conservatives were determined to block any progress toward agreement
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: "At every stage, they sought to put obstacles in the way," says one source
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: Another confirms:"The Tories kept throwing spanners in the works."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: According to a third:"All the parties, including Ukip, took part in good faith except the Conservatives."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: Last time around, "a heads of agreement" about the debates had been written by December
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: This time around, we have got to mid-January and aren't even close to that
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The last meeting was just before Christmas
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: "We didn't get anywhere because of the Tories," says one source, an account that is again corroborated by others
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: I have learned that a meeting between the parties and the broadcasters was scheduled for the Thursday just gone
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: It was cancelled at the last minute by the Conservatives
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: No new date has been set
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The prime minister's latest excuse for nobbling debates is that he won't do it unless the Greens are included
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: I happen to agree that the Greens ought to be represented in one debate
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: There is not much logic to Ofcom's recent preliminary recommendation that Ukip and the Lib Dems should be treated as "major" parties for the purposes of allocating airtime during the campaign, but not the Greens
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: They have been nip and tuck with the Lib Dems in the opinion polls and quite often done better
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: They have had representation in the House of Commons for longer than Ukip
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: So I agree that it would be fair to include the Greens - and hoot with laughter to hear that argument coming out of the mouth of David Cameron
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: When did he become obsessed with championing the rights of minority parties?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Who knew he had such a passion to debate with Natalie Bennett?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: In the history of political excuses, this must go down as one of the most terrible
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: By running away from debates, the Tories are taking some risk with their leader's reputation and sense of himself
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Says one senior government figure:"Cameron doesn't like being called chicken."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: If
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: the Cameron brand is supposed to be the strong and confident leader
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: why is he frit of debating Ed Miliband, a man the Tories keep telling us is hopelessly weak?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Won't it simply look bad to deny TV debates to the voters?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Yes, it will
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: but
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: the Tories are calculating that any fuss will be short- lived, soon forgotten and, in the end, not that many voters will punish them for it, especially if their spinners can successfully sow confusion about who is responsible
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The Tories also bargain that the press won't make that big a deal of it
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: About that, they may be right
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: There was resentment among newspapers during the last campaign that their capacity to shape the agenda was reduced by the TV debates
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: There are journalists and editors who will be secretly happy if they don't happen again
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: As
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: things stand
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: I think the chances of TV election debates happening are somewhere between zilch and nada
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Could anything change that?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Some suggest that the broadcasters should call David Cameron's bluff and threaten to stage debates without him - "empty chair" him in the jargon
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Labour and the Lib Dems hope this will happen
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Number 10 is assuming that the BBC wouldn't have the nerve
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: the other broadcasters will follow its lead
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: holding a debate without Mr Cameron might anyway be a breach of the laws about election coverage
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: A debate between everyone but the prime minister could even suit the Tories when they want to project him as the statesman floating above the fray
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: A more realistic way to flush him out would be to strip him of the Green figleaf he is using as his pretext for not debating
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The broadcasters could redraft their proposal to include Natalie Bennett in one of the debates
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Labour, the Lib Dems and Ukip could say that they'd be content for her to participate
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: I think they would
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Labour and the Lib Dems aren't keen on including the Greens
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: who have been taking votes off both of them
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: but
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: when it comes to the crunch, they'd rather have a debate with the Greens than no debates at all
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Even then, the Tories are so determined to avoid TV debates that they'd most likely concoct another pretext for sabotaging them
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: But at least everyone would then be crystal clear who is to blame
paragraphs.label: assumption
